name: RBN-2B "Zenith"
description: The most capable tier-2 raygun robonaut, the Zenith combines an X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analyzer with a high-power pulsed diode-pumped solid-state laser (DPSSL) operating at 1.06 μm. The XRF emitter illuminates surface patches at 200,000 km standoff — roughly half the Earth-Moon distance — with polychromatic X-ray pulses; the fluorescent return spectrum is decoded by a cooled silicon-drift detector array to yield element mass fractions for Si, Fe, Mg, Ca, Ti, Al, and key volatiles. At this range an Earth-orbiting ship can fully characterise the entire near-side and limb of the Moon in a single observation window. This makes the Zenith the first robonaut capable of quantitative mineral abundance estimates rather than mere spectral classification. Its 12 MW electric consumption drives both the X-ray tube bank and the 8 kW pulsed laser, which provides genuine industrial-scale ice melting when surface-deployed at over 3 tonnes per hour. Named for the highest point of the celestial sphere — pointing straight up and straight down simultaneously.
